name: Angular
description: together with React and Vue.js one of the three most popular JavaScript frameworks

name: CI/CD
description: the combined practices of continuous integration (CI) and continuous deployment (CD)

name: React
description: currently the most popular front-end JavaScript framework along with Vue and Angular

name: Swagger
description: a suite of tools for API developers created in 2011

name: REST
description: a way to make services on a web available to software and other websites

name: GitLab
description: a popular tool to organize the lifecyle of software development - a local GitHub

name: UI/UX
description: how a user interacts with and experiences a software application including the person's perceptions of utility, ease of use, and efficiency

name: Testing
description: 1. unit tests, 2. integration tests, 3. end-to-end tests

name: Bootstrap
description: a ubiquitous CSS framework that simplifies website design

name: styled-components
description: a React tool created in 2016 that allows developers to write CSS-in-JS, enabling styling of components using tagged template literals

name: Storybook
description: a tool for UI development that makes development faster and easier by isolating components

name: FuseBox
description: module bundler that is simple to configure but has enough features to be a valid alternative to WebPack

name: Jasmine
description: an open-source testing framework for JavaScript

name: Hotjar
description: a software tool to track users

name: Piwik
description: a tool to track a customer's behavior across websites and apps

name: TypeScript
description: in larger applications, the preferred way to program in JavaScript

name: Jest
description: a JavaScript testing framework like Mocha, but simpler

name: Git
description: the most-used revision control system today

name: Next.js
description: a React framework that enables server-side rendering

name: NestJS
description: a Node.js framework for building efficient, reliable and scalable server-side applications

name: Responsive web design
description: an approach to web design that aims to make web pages render well on a variety of devices and window or screen sizes from minimum to maximum display size to ensure usability and satisfaction

name: PWA
description: (Progressive Web Apps) a web application concept created by Google in 2015 that utilizes modern web capabilities to provide users with a native app-like experience directly through their web browser

name: HTML
description: the markup language that serves as the basis of websites

name: CSS
description: the language used to style websites and a standard tool for web development

name: JavaScript
description: the main scripting language of the Web

name: Mocha
description: one of the most popular JavaScript testing frameworks

name: Vue.js
description: can easily be used to enhance existing applications as well as to create new applications

name: MVC
description: an architectural pattern commonly used particularly in web development

name: C
description: low-level language used to program everything from hardware devices to operating systems

name: C++
description: low-level language for writing applications

name: Java
description: a popular and ubiquitous OOP programming language

name: C#
description: the standard OOP language on the .NET platform

name: MVVM
description: a pattern like MVC but with a View Model, gave rise to JavaScript frameworks

name: Azure
description: a cloud computing service created by Microsoft for building, testing, deploying, and managing applications and services

name: AWS
description: a subsidiary of Amazon that provides on-demand cloud computing platforms

name: GCP
description: a suite of cloud computing services that runs on the same infrastructure that Google uses internally for its end-user products, such as Google Search, Gmail and YouTube

name: SQL
description: the standard language you use to get data from relational databases

name: NoSQL
description: a type of non-table database used with big data

name: SAP
description: a German software company and world's leading enterprise resource planning (ERP) software vendor

name: XML
description: markup language for defining and transmitting data and documents

name: JSON
description: a popular standard for storing and transmitting information and data objects, particularly in JavaScript

name: Agile
description: a philosophy of software developer which includes adaptive planning, evolutionary development, early delivery, continual improvement, and flexible responses to changes in requirements, capacity, and understanding of the problems to be solved

name: Scrum
description: a framework for project management designed for teams of ten or fewer members who break their work into goals that can be completed within time-boxed iterations, called sprints, no longer than one month and most commonly two weeks

name: Gitflow
description: a branching and merging methodology popularized by the blog post "A Successful Git branching model", older, seems overly complicated and controversial

name: Domain-Driven Design
description: a software design approach focused on modeling software to match a domain according to input from that domain's experts

name: microservices
description: an architectural pattern that arranges an application as a collection of loosely-coupled, fine-grained services, communicating through lightweight protocols, one goal being that teams can develop and deploy their services independently of others

name: .NET
description: the main Windows development framework since 2001

name: Entity Framework
description: object-relational mapping (ORM) framework for .NET

name: Hangfire
description: easy way to perform background processing in .NET and .NET Core applications

name: RabbitMQ
description: message-broker software that originally implemented AMQP

name: MUI
description: (Material UI) a popular React component library created in 2014 that implements Google's Material Design principles to provide a modern, customizable, and accessible set of UI components for building web applications

name: GraphQL
description: a newer and more robust alternative to REST

name: Apollo
description: the most popular GraphQL client created in 2016 that allows developers to efficiently query, cache, and manage data with GraphQL in client-side applications

name: ASP.NET
description: the Microsoft .NET standard approach for developing websites

name: Docker
description: a software virtualization solution that allows each application to run in a separate container

name: Kubernetes
description: platform used for large-scale application automation including Docker

name: OpenShift
description: a family of containerization software products developed by Red Hat, similar to Kubernetes

name: NUnit
description: an open-source unit testing framework for the .NET Framework and Mono

name: Rider
description: a cross-platform IDE for .NET by JetBrains

name: DevOps Server
description: an Azure tool to share code, track work, and ship software using integrated software delivery tools, hosted on-premises

name: MongoDB
description: the most popular NoSQL document store database

name: cloud computing
description: on-demand and scalable availability of computer system resources, usually AWS, Azure or Google Cloud Platform

name: Kotlin
description: Google's new Java language

name: Swift
description: Apple's general-purpose, multi-paradigm, compiled programming language, developed as a replacement for Apple's earlier programming language Objective-C

name: Jetpack Compose
description: Android's recommended modern toolkit for building native UI

name: Firebase
description: a platform developed by Google for creating mobile and web applications

name: Flutter
description: Google's software development kit for mobile apps

name: Dart
description: a Google replacement for JavaScript which transpiles to JavaScript

name: Node
description: central JavaScript technology for web backend and application development

name: Express
description: a web application framework for Node.js and the de facto Node standard for building web applications and APIs

name: Magento
description: an e-commerce PHP framework created in 2008, now owned by Adobe

name: JQuery
description: a useful and popular but older JavaScript library

name: PHP
description: a popular and pragmatic programming language for websites created in 1994

name: MySQL
description: a popular and widespread database for websites and applications

name: Apache
description: a old, classic and popular web server from the 90s

name: Nginx
description: a fast web server that can also be used as a reverse proxy, load balancer, mail proxy and HTTP cache

name: Webpack
description: an older, slower but popular web bundler

name: WebStorm
description: an integrated development environment for JavaScript and related technologies

name: Rollup
description: a module bundler created in 2015 used by Vite and becoming increasingly popular

name: MINT
description: Bezeichnung von und Studienfächern aus den Bereichen Mathematik, Informatik, Naturwissenschaft und Technik, auf Englisch STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics)

name: machine learning
description: a part of artificial intelligence, ML algorithms build a model based on sample data, known as training data, in order to make predictions or decisions without being explicitly programmed to do so

name: Python
description: an older but pragmatic language and increasingly popular today used widely by scientists and mathematicians

name: Python Science Stack
description: a set of libraries for scientific computation and visualization including Python, NumPy, SciPy, matplotlib, IPython, pandas, SymPy and Jupyter Notebook

name: scikit-learn
description: a set of simple and efficient tools for predictive data analysis built on NumPy, SciPy and matplotlib

name: OOP
description: (Object-Oriented Programming) a programming paradigm based on the concept of objects, which can contain data and code, the data is in the form of properties and the code is in the form of methods, contrast with functional programming

name: Tensorflow
description: Google Brain's second-generation system focus on training and inference of deep neural networks

name: PyTorch
description: a machine learning framework based on the Torch library, used for applications such as computer vision and natural language processing

name: code review
description: the act of consciously and systematically convening with one’s fellow programmers to check each other’s code for mistakes and has been repeatedly shown to accelerate and streamline the process of software development

name: pair programming
description: technique in which two programmers work together at one workstation

name: Spring Boot
description: a tool that makes it easy to create stand-alone, production-grade Spring-based Applications for the Java platform

name: Serverless Computing
description: a misnomer in the sense that servers are still used by cloud service providers to execute code for developers, however, developers of serverless applications are not concerned with capacity planning, configuration, management, maintenance, fault tolerance, or scaling of containers, VMs, or physical servers

name: CQRS
description: (Command Query Responsibility Singleton) a pattern popularized around 2010 that separates the read and write operations for a data store to improve scalability, performance, and maintainability

name: microfrontends
description: what you get when you bring the microservice approach to the frontend, a frontend made of components owned by different teams that can be deployed independently

name: Tailwind
description: a highly customizable, low-level, low-opinionated CSS framework

name: GitHub Actions
description: a continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD) platform that allows you to automate your build, test, and deployment pipeline

name: Fluent UI
description: a Microsoft collection of UX frameworks for creating cross-platform apps

name: TypeORM
description: an ORM that can be run with TypeScript, connect multiple databases, and can run in NodeJS, Browser, Cordova, PhoneGap, Ionic, React Native, NativeScript, Expo, and Electron platforms

name: PostgreSQL
description: a robust but less popular SQL database than MySQL

name: Redis
description: the most popular key-value database

name: ZenHub
description: an agile project management tool designed to help software teams organize, plan, track, and manage their work, available either inside GitHub via a browser extension or as a standalone web app

name: Ionic Appflow
description: a CI/CD platform for Ionic development teams that helps development teams continuously build and ship their Cordova, Capacitor, and React Native apps

name: Lambda
description: (AWS Lambda) Amazon's serverless compute service that enables developers to run code in response to events without managing servers, automatically scaling to handle varying workloads and billed only for the compute time consumed

name: Salesforce
description: a cloud-based software company which provides customer relationship management (CRM) software and applications focused on sales, customer service, marketing automation, analytics, and application development

name: Microsoft Dynamics
description: a collection of 12 applications used for enterprise resource planning (ERP) and customer relationship management (CRM) for intelligent business applications, announced by Microsoft in July 2016

name: GitHub
description: the standard platform to store, publish, and share code projects on the web

name: DevOps
description: set of practices that combines software development and IT operations which aims to shorten the systems development life cycle and provide continuous delivery with high software quality

name: Clean Code
description: a set of coding principles which include: follow conventions, keep it simple, leave code cleaner than when you found it, always find the root cause

name: Cypress
description: a testing tool that automates and scales end-to-end testing

name: Open API
description: an API that is open for use by developers with relatively few restrictions, typically without copyright restrictions

name: Redux
description: JavaScript library for maintaining state, used with React and Angular

name: Sass
description: a preprocessor scripting language that is interpreted or compiled into Cascading Style Sheets

name: Jira
description: popular bug and issue-tracking software

name: Confluence
description: a web-based corporate wiki

name: Jenkins
description: an older but popular build automation tool still used in many companies

name: SSR
description: in contrast to client-side rendering, server-side rendering generates static content on the server before sending it over to the user's browser, which better addresses performance and search engine optimization issues of single-page JavaScript applications

name: Remix
description: a React framework used for server-side rendering (SSR) and unlike Next.js, it enables nested routing with nested layouts

name: Chakra UI
description: a simple, modular and accessible component library that gives you the building blocks you need to build your React applications

name: React Native
description: a popular JavaScript framework for building mobile apps

name: LiveKit
description: an open source WebRTC project that gives you everything needed to build scalable and real-time audio, video, and data experiences in applications

name: Socket.IO
description: JavaScript library that enables realtime, bi-directional communication between web clients and servers

name: Terraform
description: infrastructure as code tool created by HashiCorp

name: Nx
description: a build-system tool to develop multiple full-stack applications that share code between them all in the same workspace

name: Babel
description: a JavaScript transpiler which enables you to use higher versions of ECMAScript

name: CircleCI
description: a continuous integration platform that helps ship software faster, using code that's reusable and easy to maintain

name: React Testing Library
description: a light-weight solution for testing React components

name: TestCafe
description: an end-to-end testing framework for web applications that runs on Node

name: SuperTest
description: provides a high-level abstraction for testing HTTP and APIs

name: Piral
description: a framework to build portal applications that follow the microfrontends architecture

name: Hetzner Cloud
description: a Germany cloud provider which operates data center parks in Germany, Finland and the USA

name: InfluxDB
description: a time-series database (for time-stampted event data) written in Go and used for storage of e.g. Internet of Things senso data and real-time analytics

name: artificial intelligence
description: software that is able to learn by itself within a specific context in order to process data to solve tasks that otherwise require human intelligence

name: React Hooks
description: Hooks are a new addition in React 16.8, they let you use state and other React features without writing a class.

name: Polymer
description: a JavaScript framework created and used by Google which embraces the Material Design ideology

name: Stencil
description: a compiler that generates web components which use TypeScript, JSX, and CSS

name: Vite
description: a tool to set up development starter applications for frameworks like Vue, React, Svelte and JS/DOM

name: A/B tests
description: the process of comparing two variations of a page element, usually by testing users' response to variant A vs. variant B and concluding which of the two variants is more effective

name: Gradle
description: a build automation tool for multi-language software development that controls the development process from compilation and packaging to testing, deployment, and publishing, supported languages include Java, Kotlin, Groovy, Scala, C/C++, and JavaScript

name: D3.js
description: a JavaScript library created in 2011 for manipulating documents based on data, enabling the creation of interactive and dynamic data visualizations in web browsers

name: Projektron BCS
description: web-based project management software for planning, managing and controlling projects simultaneously, founded 2001 in Berlin

name: Svelte
description: JavaScript framework that generates code to manipulate the DOM

name: Tomcat
description: a free and open-source Java web application server

name: JBoss
description: a free and open-source Java application server developed by Red Hat that implements the Java Enterprise Edition specification, today known as WildFly

name: MQTT
description: a lightweight, publish-subscribe, machine to machine network protocol for Message queue/Message queuing service

name: AMQP
description: an open standard application layer protocol for message-oriented middleware responsible for orientation, queuing, and has both point-to-point  and publish-and-subscribe routing

name: Maven
description: a build automation tool used primarily for Java projects which can also be used to build and manage projects written in C#, Ruby, and Scala

name: MariaDB
description: a community-developed, commercially supported fork of MySQL

name: Gitlab CI
description: a feature of GitLab which provides build automation, test automation, pipeline config management, artifact storage, and pipeline security

name: FastAPI
description: a modern, fast, web framework for building APIs with Python

name: Go
description: a language created by Google that resembles C but with some object-oriented features

name: EKS
description: AWS's container platform (Elastic Kubernetes Service)

name: Python/Qt
description: a Python library that enables developers to use Python to write Qt applications

name: Hibernate
description: the leading ORM for Java which provides mapping from the OOP model in Java to the table model in databases like MySQL and Postgres

name: Linux Admin
description: skills including installing and managing an online Linux machine, basic commands, devices and filesystems, shells and scripting, user interfaces, administrative tasks, system services, networking fundamentals, and security

name: SQLite
description: a small database engine written in the C programming language, not an app but merely a library which developers embed in theri apps, hence it belongs to the family of embedded databases

name: Zend
description: an older corporate-owned PHP framework created in 2006

name: LaTeX
description: a software system for document preparation in which the writer uses plain text as opposed to formatted text found in WYSIWYG word processors, widely used in academia

name: big data
description: the processing of data sets too large and complex to be dealt with by traditional databases

name: data lake
description: a repository of data stored in its raw format such as object blobs (binary large objects, e.g. images or audio) or other various files, usually consisting of both (1) raw copies of system data, sensor data or social data, plus (2) transformed data used for tasks such as reporting, visualization, advanced analytics and machine learning

name: data pipelines
description: a series of data processing steps in which each step delivers an output that is the input for the next step

name: Kafka
description: open-source stream-processing software platform developed by the Apache Software Foundation

name: Bitbucket
description: the second most popular version control hosting service, originally hosted Mercurial since 2008 but hosts Git since 2011, owned by Atlassian who owns Jira

name: fabric8
description: a now discontinued open source DevOps and Integration Platform which works with Kubernetes or OpenShift environment and provides Continuous Delivery

name: DynamoDB
description: Amazon's NoSQL cloud database service

name: TDD
description: (Test-driven development) a software development process relying on software requirements being converted to test cases before software is fully developed

name: functional programming
description: a programming paradigm where programs are constructed by applying and composing functions, where functions can be passed as arguments and returned from other functions just as any other data type can

name: OpenUI5
description: a JavaScript framework and UI library created by SAP, OpenUI5 is the open-source version of SAPUI5

name: CouchDB
description: a NoSQL document database, less popular than MongoDB

name: Google Cloud Platform
description: suite of cloud computing services that runs on the same infrastructure that Google uses internally for its end-user products

name: Behavior-Driven Development (BDD)
description: an agile software development process that encourages collaboration among developers, quality assurance experts, and customer representatives in a software project, using conversation and concrete examples to formalize a shared understanding of how the application should behave

name: DDD
description: (Domain-Driven Design) an approach to software design that focuses on modeling software to match a domain according to input from that domain's experts

name: Internet of Things (IoT)
description: physical objects with sensors, processing ability, software and other technologies that connect and exchange data with other devices and systems over the Internet

name: Blockchain
description: a distributed ledger with growing lists of records (blocks) that are securely linked together via cryptographic hashes

name: SAAS
description: (Software as a service) a software licensing and delivery model in which software is licensed on a subscription basis and is centrally hosted

name: MobX
description: an alternative state management tools which is a good alternative to Redux giving the same functionality with less code to write

name: Headless CMS
description: a backend-only web content management system that acts primarily as a content repository accessible via an API or GraphQL

name: Contentful
description: a content management system (CMS) that allows developers to create, manage, and distribute digital content across multiple platforms and devices

name: Storyblok
description: a headless content management system that focuses on creating better content experiences for users

name: Ionic/Cordova
description: allows you to build hybrid mobile apps with CSS, HTML and JavaScript

name: FeathersJS
description: an API and real-time application network

name: Nuxt
description: a web framework that extends Vue.js for server-rendering and static sites

name: Flask
description: a micro web framework written in Python

name: Blazor
description: a web framework like Angular but instead of using TypeScript, you use C# and the template markup syntax Razor

name: Websockets
description: a communication protocol that provides communication channels over a single, long-lived connection between a web browser and a server

name: Ruby on Rails
description: an older web application framework from 2005 with useful framework paradigms worth learning

name: Laravel
description: PHP framework released 2013 now most popular PHP framework

name: Yii PHP Framework
description: an open source, object-oriented, component-based MVC PHP web application framework

name: Karma
description: A JavaScript testing tool that is primarily designed for low-level unit testing

name: NativeScript
description: framework to develop mobile apps on the Apple iOS and Android platforms

name: Objective-C
description: a language necessary for programming Apple devices

name: Grunt
description: an old (2012) JavaScript task runner, used to automatically perform frequent tasks such as minification, compilation, unit testing, and linting, older than Gulp (2017)

name: Gulp
description: a task runner built on Node.js, designed to automate repetitive tasks in web development workflows, similar to but newer than Grunt

name: Symfony
description: a popular PHP framework created in 2007, today second in popularity behind Laravel

name: Twig
description: a template engine for PHP

name: SVN
description: an older software versioning system (2000) used before Git became popular

name: monorepos
description: single repositories that contain multiple distinct projects, with well-defined relationships

name: Scala
description: a Java-like language with more functional features

name: Puppeteer
description: a Node.js library that enables you to control a Chromium browser programatically

name: Playwright
description: an end-to-end testing tool similar to Cypress

name: VBA
description: Visual Basic for Applications, a simple language still used to program business analysist and statistic applications in Excel

name: Visual Studio
description: the default coding editor for .NET technologies

name: SAPUI5
description: a JavaScript framework and UI library created by SAP which has proprietary features and hence is not open-source as is OpenUI5 which is the same framework but without the propreitary features

name: Algolia
description: a search as a service product offering web search across a client's website using an externally hosted search engine

name: Prisma
description: Node.js and TypeScript ORM for Postgres, MySQL, SQLite, AWS Aurora, Azure SQL, Microsoft SQL Server, MongoDB and CockroachDB

name: Vercel
description: cloud hosting provider founded in 2015 that maintains Next.js and connects to GitHub repositories for seamless deployment

name: Netlify
description: cloud hosting provider that owns Gatsby and connects to GitHub repositories for seamless deployment

name: DigitalOcean
description: an cloud service provider where you can host Linux machines for under $10 per month

name: Tableau
description: data visualization software created in 2003 acquired by Salesforce in 2019

name: Vuetify
description: a Material-UI component framework for Vue

name: Quasar
description: a front-end framework powered by Vue used to build responsive SPAs, SSR apps, PWAs, mobile apps, and Electron apps, all with the same code base

name: Microsoft SQL Server
description: an SQL server developed in 1989 which serves as the standard database for .NET projects

name: Artifactory
description: a universal repository manager supporting most major packaging formats, build tools and CI servers

name: Pinia
description: a state management tool for Vue.js created in 2019, now recommended by the Vue.js core team

name: Web accessibility
description: the inclusive practice of ensuring there are no barriers that prevent interaction by people with physical disabilities

name: Vitest
description: a test runner much like Jest that natively supports TypeScript, created in 2020 by Evan You, creator of Vue.js

name: Elasticsearch
description: a search engine and NOSQL database based on the Lucene library

name: Wordpress
description: most popular content management system written in PHP

name: Django
description: a Python-based web framework created in 2005

name: Ansible
description: a suite of tools that enables infrastructure as code including provisioning, configuration management and deployment

name: Prometheus
description: event monitoring and alerting software and time-series database written in Go which helps identify bottlenecks and optimize performance

name: Grafana
description: an analytics and interactive visualization tool that helps devops visualize and analyze system data in real-time

name: Datadog
description: an observability service for cloud-scale applications, providing monitoring of servers, databases, tools, and services

name: Hadoop
description: a collection of utilities that uses a network of computers to solve problems such as data crunching and computation

name: Apache Spark
description: analytics engine for large-scale data processing. Spark provides an interface for programming clusters with fault tolerance and data parallelism (multiple processors that work on data at once)

name: ARM (Azure Resource Manager)
description: Microsoft's deployment and management service for Azure, used to create, update, and delete Azure resources

name: Puppet
description: a configuration management tool that automates the deployment and management of software and systems

name: Helm
description: a free, open-source software that helps devops manage, deploy and version control their applications on Kubernetes clusters

name: Salt
description: an open-source configuration management and automation software tool used to manage and provision servers, cloud resources, and software applications

name: VMware Tanzu
description: a suite of products and solutions that allow its customers to build, run, and manage Kubernetes-controlled, container-based applications

name: CVS
description: a very old revision control system, its latest release in 2008

name: Canvas
description: an HTML5 feature that allows you to draw and render graphics, such as lines, shapes, images, and text, dynamically using JavaScript

name: Qt
description: an old cross-platform application development framework created in 1990

name: Oracle
description: an older, expensive SQL-based database created in 1979 used mainly for large data warehousing projects

name: SEO
description: the practice of enhancing a website's visibility and ranking on search engines like Google

name: Gatsby
description: static site generator build on React and GraphQL, now owned by Netlify

name: Rust
description: a newer lower-level language like C++ with better memory safety

name: Couchbase
description: also known as Membase, and different than CouchDB, this is an open-source, distributed, multi-model NoSQL document-oriented database software package optimized for interactive applications

name: BigQuery
description: fully managed and serverless data warehouse and analytics platform provided by Google Cloud

name: Graphite
description: a monitoring tool that runs equally well on cheap hardware or Cloud infrastructure, teams use Graphite to track the performance of their websites, applications, business services, and networked servers

name: Emotion
description: a library designed for writing css styles with JavaScript

name: Percy
description: visual testing as a service which integrates workflows to get an insight into product changes

name: SpeedCurve
description: tools to visualize how users experience the speed of your website to identify and fix performance issues

name: Varnish
description: content delivery software

name: Cloudfront
description: Amazon's CDN (content delivery service) which caches and stores copies of content in edge locations around the world

name: S3
description: Amazon's cloud storage service aber to store and retrieve any amount of data on the web

name: SNS
description: Amazon's Simple Notification Service, a managed messaging service that sends messages to a distributed set of recipients in a publish-subscribe model

name: Cognito
description: Amazon's managed identity and access management service which simplifies and secures user idenity management

name: Adobe XD
description: a vector design tool for web and mobile applications, creates user interfaces for mobile and web apps, however now in maintenance mode

name: Sketch
description: a vector graphics editor for macOS primarily used for user interface and user experience design of websites and mobile apps

name: Figma
description: design and prototyping tool used in the field of user interface (UI) and user experience (UX) design

name: Ant-Design
description: design system and UI framework primarily used for building web and mobile applications

name: Groovy
description: optionally typed and dynamic language for the Java platform

name: Capacitor
description: an open source native runtime for building Web Native apps. Create cross-platform iOS, Android, and Progressive Web Apps with JavaScript, HTML, and CSS

name: Google Pub/Sub
description: a messaging service that enables asynchronous communication between applications, allowing them to exchange real-time data reliably and at scale

name: gRPC
description: an open-source framework for building scalable distributed systems, facilitating communication between services using a language-agnostic binary protocol

name: SOLID principles
description: SOLID is an acronym for the first five object-oriented design principles by Robert Martin: 1. each class has (S)ingle responsibility, 2. software entities should be (O) to extension by closed for modification, 3. you should be able to replace superclass with a subclass according to the (L)iskov Subsitution Principle, 4. a class should be no forced to implement (I)nterfaces it does not use, 5. abstractions should not depend on details; details should depend on abstractions, according to the (D)ependency Inversion Principle

name: Cloud-Native
description: an approach in software development that utilizes cloud computing to build applications in modern, dynamic environments such as public, private, and hybrid clouds with technologies such as containers, microservices, serverless functions, cloud native processors and immutable infrastructure

name: AWS CodePipeline
description: a fully managed continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD) platform that automates the build, test, and deployment phases of your release process, facilitating efficient application delivery in the cloud

name: SOAP
description: Simple Object Access Protocol, created 1998, was a protocol for exchanging structured information in web services, using XML as its message format, to facilitate communication between disparate systems over the internet, less used today as REST and GraphQL are often considered more lightweight and simpler alternatives to SOAP for most types of web services

name: Strapi
description: an open-source headless content management system (CMS) that enables developers to build flexible and customizable APIs for content delivery across various digital platforms

name: EJS
description: (Embedded JavaScript templating), a templating language that enables the embedding of JavaScript code within HTML markup to dynamically generate content on the server side, similar to Handlebars and Pug

name: Materialize
description: a responsive front-end framework based on Google's Material Design guidelines, providing a smaller set of components than Material UI (MUI), thus focusing on simplicity and ease of use

name: Chai
description: an assertion library for node and the browser that can be paired with any javascript testing framework, usually Mocha

name: UML
description: a general-purpose visual modeling language that is intended to provide a standard way to visualize the design of a data system and the layering of an object-oriented class model on top of a purely relational database

name: Extreme Programming
description: a software development methodology intended to improve software quality and responsiveness to changing customer requirements

name: OpenSearch
description: a collection of technologies that allow the publishing of search results in a format suitale for syndication and aggregation

name: Leaflet
description: open-source JavaScript library for mobile-friendly interactive maps

name: Mapbox
description: AI-powered location technology for automakers, mobile app developers, and logistics services

name: Web Vitals
description: Chrome extension that helps you deliver better UX by providing feedback on loading, interactivity and layout shift metrics

name: ZeroMQ
description: an open-source universal messaging library that functions as an embeddable networking library and a concurrency framework

name: Kinesis
description: a stream processing service offered by AWS that simplifies the capture, processing, and storage of data streams

name: .NET Core
description: .NET Core is a free, open-source, and cross-platform software development framework maintained by Microsoft that can run on Windows, macOS, and Linux.

name: Ember.js
description: a full-featured JavaScript Web Framework that uses convention over configuration and MVVM, a wholesale solution, peaked around 2014

name: augmented reality
description: a system that incorporates three basic features: a combination of real and virtual worlds, real-time interaction, and accurate 3D registration of virtual and real objects

name: Electron
description: a framework for building cross-platform desktop applications using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript

name: Kibana
description: a tool for data analytics, security, search, threat intelligence, search analytics, logs and application monitoring

name: Ruby
description: a dynamic, object-oriented programming language created in the 1990s known for its simplicity and productivity

name: JWT
description: a technology for representing claims to be transferred between two parties securely, typically used to transmit information about an authenticated user for a web application

name: Selenium
description: an testing framework primarily used for web applications, older than Cypress and Playwright

name: Perl
description: an interpreted language from the 1990s known for its versatility and ability to handle many various tasks, including text processing, system administration, web development and network programming

name: Adobe CC
description: Adobe's software as a service model which gives subscribers access to all of their software such as Photoshop (photos, images), Illustrator (vector graphics), Acrobat (PDFs), InDesign (desktop publishing), Premiere (video editing), After Effects (multimedia projects), Lightroom (batch photo editing), XD (like Figma), Dreamweaver (web development), and Audition (audio editing)

name: Jinja
description: a popular templating engine for Python used to generate dynamic content for web applications allowing developers to embed Python-like expressions and statements into templates, which are then rendered into HTML pages, widely used with Flask and Django

name: MLOps
description: the practice of deploying and maintaining machine learning models to ensure production reliably and efficiently

name: pytest
description: a framework makes it easy to write small, readable tests, and can scale to support complex functional testing for applications and libraries

name: CAD
description: (Computer-Aided Design) technology that allows users to create, modify, and optimize digital representations of physical objects or systems before they are built

name: P&ID
description: (Piping and Instrumentation Diagram) programming involves designing and implementing control systems for industrial processes using graphical representations of piping, instrumentation, and control equipment

name: SolidJS
description: a JavaScript library for building user interfaces with a fine-grained reactive system and compile-time optimizations for efficiency, distinguishing itself from other frameworks like React or Vue

name: OAuth2
description: authorization framework that allows third-party services to access a user's resources without exposing their credentials, by providing tokens instead

name: OIDC
description: an authentication layer built on top of OAuth 2.0, providing a standardized way for clients to verify the identity of end-users based on the authentication performed by an authorization server

name: JPA
description: the Java Persistence API provides Java developers with an object/relational mapping facility for managing relational data in Java applications. Java Persistence consists of four areas

name: HATEOAS
description: (Hypermedia as the Engine of Application State) is a constraint in REST architecture where clients interact with a server through hypermedia links provided dynamically in the responses, enabling navigation of the application's state

name: HAL
description: (Hypertext Application Language) is a convention for defining hypermedia such as links to external resources within JSON or XML code

name: Podman
description: a collection of container tools to seamlessly work with containers and Kubernetes from your local environment

name: Keycloak
description: a single-signon service that provides user federation, strong authentication, user management, fine-grained authorization

name: JFrog
description: leading provider of universal DevOps technology solutions, including artifact repository management and software distribution platforms

name: Sonatype Nexus
description: a widely used repository manager that helps organizations manage and distribute software artifacts and dependencies throughout the software development lifecycle

name: SonarQube
description: an open-source platform developed by SonarSource for continuous inspection of code quality to perform automatic reviews with static analysis of code to detect bugs and code smells on 29 programming languages

name: ECS
description: (Elastic Container Service) is a container orchestration service that simplifies deployment, management, and scaling of Docker containers on AWS infrastructure

name: RDS
description: (Relational Database Service) is an AWS database service that simplifies setting up, operating, and scaling relational databases in the cloud, supporting various database engines like MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, and Oracle

name: CloudWatch
description: a monitoring and observability service that provides real-time insights into AWS resources and applications, allowing users to collect and track metrics, set alarms, and automatically react to changes in their AWS environment

name: Knockout.js
description: a JavaScript library that simplifies the implementation of dynamic user interfaces with Model-View-ViewModel (MVVM) architecture, created in 2010, rarely used anymore in production but often referenced as a significant step towards JavaScript frameworks

name: Backbone
description: a lightweight JavaScript library with a RESTful JSON interface and based on the Model View Presenter (MVP) application design paradigm, created in 2010 and peaked in popularity about 2013

name: Google Tag Manager
description: a tag management system created in 2012 that allows users to easily manage and deploy tags on their website without needing to modify the code, in order to track user interactions, analyze website performance, run marketing campaigns

name: Google Analytics
description: a web analytics service created in 2005 that allows website owners to track, analyze, and report on their website's traffic and user behavior

name: Ext JS
description: a JavaScript framework created in 2007 for building cross-platform web applications with a rich user interface and extensive component library

name: Elixir
description: a functional, concurrent programming language created in 2011 on the Erlang virtual machine known for its scalability and fault-tolerance

name: Unity
description: a cross-platform game engine created in 2005 known for its versatility and ease of use, enabling developers to create interactive 2D and 3D content

name: Mattermost
description: an open-source, self-hostable Slack-like messaging platform created in 2015 with which you can create team communication channels, share files, conduct video calls, integrate with third-party services, and automate workflows using bots

name: Whereby
description: a browser-based video conferencing platform created in 2013 that allows users to host and join video meetings without the need for downloads or installations

name: Sentry
description: an open-source application monitoring platform created in 2008 that helps developers track and fix errors in real-time across the software development lifecycle

name: Traefik
description: an open-source reverse proxy and load balancer created in 2014 that helps developers deploy microservices with ease by providing dynamic configuration and integration with container orchestration platforms like Docker and Kubernetes

name: ELK stack
description: (Elastic Stack) comprised of Elasticsearch, Kibana, Beats, and Logstash, enables developers to search, analyze, and visualize any data from any source, in any format

name: Less
description: a dynamic stylesheet language created in 2009 that extends CSS with features like variables, mixins, and functions

name: PostCSS
description: a tool for transforming CSS with JavaScript plugins created 2013

name: Ajax
description: (Asynchronous JavaScript and XML) is a general technique used since 1999 in web development to create interactive and dynamic user interfaces by allowing web pages to retrieve data from the server asynchronously without interfering with the display and behavior of the existing page

name: Blueprint.js
description: a React-based UI toolkit created in 2016 for building complex, data-dense web interfaces

name: Docker Swarm
description: a container orchestration tool for clustering and scheduling Docker containers

name: GitOps
description: a standard workflow for application development that uses Git repositories as a single source of truth to deliver infrastructure as code

name: AWS Aurora
description: a proprietary relational database offered as a service by Amazon, MySQL compatible since 2014, Postgres compatible since 2017

name: Lit
description: a lightweight web component library released in 2020 that simplifies building web components using TypeScript

name: Jakarta Faces
description: a Java-based MVC framework created in 2004 for building user interfaces for web applications using reusable UI components, renamed in 2018 from JavaServer Faces (JSF)

name: Airflow
description: (Apache Airflow) is an open-source platform created in 2014 used to programmatically author, schedule, and monitor complex workflows

name: Celery
description: an open-source, asynchronous task queue/job queue created in 2009 and based on distributed message passing and used to execute tasks concurrently or on schedule

name: R
description: a programming language and environment for statistical computing and graphics created in 1993

name: SPFx
description: (SharePoint Framework) a framework introduced by Microsoft in 2016 that enables building web parts and extensions for SharePoint using React and Angular, allowing developers to use client-side scripting and open-source tooling for creating responsive and mobile-friendly SharePoint solutions

name: OpenID
description: an open standard and decentralized authentication protocol created in 2005 that allows users to use a single set of login credentials to access multiple websites without needing to create new accounts

name: EDA
description: (Event-Driven Architecture) a software design paradigm where the flow of the program is determined by events such as user actions, sensor outputs, or messages from other programs, and allows systems to be highly responsive, scalable, and adaptable to real-time information

name: RxDB
description: a real-time NoSQL database created in 2017 for JavaScript applications designed to enable client-side and offline-first data persistence with synchronization capabilities

name: Fly.io
description: a platform created in 2017 that allows developers to deploy and run full-stack applications close to their users by providing a global network of micro VMs, and supports several databases including PostgreSQL, Redis, and SQLite for scalable and efficient data management

name: Snowpack
description: a build tool for web development, faster than Webpack and Parcel, but as of April 20, 2022 no longer actively maintained and is not recommended for new projects

name: RxJS
description: a library created in 2015 for composing asynchronous and event-based programs using observable sequences in JavaScript

name: New Relic
description: a software analytics and performance monitoring platform created in 2008 that helps developers gain insights into their applications and infrastructure in real-time

name: OWASP 10
description: (Open Web Application Security Project) a standard awareness document for developers and web application security, which represents a broad consensus about the most critical security risks to web applications

name: React Query
description: a data-fetching and state management library for React applications created in 2019, designed to simplify data synchronization between your server and client, offering features like caching, background updates, and synchronization

name: xUnit
description: an open-source unit testing framework for .NET created in 2004, it enables developers to write unit tests in C# and other .NET languages

name: Jamstack
description: (JavaScript, APIs, and Markup) a modern web development architecture introduced in 2016 which emphasizes decoupling the front end from the backend, using pre-rendered static content enhanced by JavaScript and APIs to deliver dynamic functionalities

name: PrimeNG
description: an open-source UI component library for Angular applications created in 2016 offering a wide range of components like data tables, charts, and form inputs to streamline the development of responsive and visually appealing user interfaces

name: WebAssembly
description: (Wasm) a binary instruction format for a stack-based virtual machine, designed to run code on web browsers with near-native performance, created in 2017 to enable high-performance applications on the web by allowing code written in multiple languages to run on the web securely and efficiently

name: fastlane
description: an open-source platform created in 2014 to automate the building and release process for mobile applications for iOS and Android apps

name: Turbo
description: enables you to publish and manage all of your enterprise applications from a single point to every platform and device

name: Turbo
description: enables you to publish and manage all of your enterprise applications from a single point to every platform and device

name: WCF
description: (Windows Communication Foundation) is a framework for building service-oriented applications on the .NET platform, introduced in 2006

name: WPF
description: (Windows Presentation Foundation) is a graphical subsystem for rendering user interfaces in .NET-based Windows applications, introduced in 2006

name: SOLR
description: an open-source enterprise search platform from the Apache Lucene project created in 2004, designed for scalability and search efficiency

name: Hasura
description: an open-source engine created in 2018 that provides instant GraphQL and REST APIs on new or existing PostgreSQL databases, enabling real-time data access and CRUD operations with built-in authorization

name: SQLAlchemy
description: a Python SQL toolkit and Object-Relational Mapping (ORM) library created in 2006 that provides database interaction capabilities using high-level abstractions and SQL expressions

name: Argo Workflows
description: an open-source container-native workflow engine created in 2017 for orchestrating parallel jobs on Kubernetes

name: OpenAI
description: an artificial intelligence research organization founded in 2015 dedicated to developing and promoting friendly AI for the benefit of humanity

name: Sumo Logic
description: a cloud-based machine data analytics company founded in 2010 providing real-time insights for IT operations, security, and business intelligence

name: Web3
description: a concept which became popular around 2014 which represents the next phase of the internet that incorporates blockchain technology, aiming to create a decentralized web where users have control over their own data and digital identities

name: shadcn
description: a React component library released in 2023 which is a collection of reusable UI components that you can copy and paste directly into your applications rather than installing them as dependencies via npm

name: Splunk
description: a software platform created in 2003 designed for searching, monitoring, and analyzing machine-generated data (big data) through a web-style interface
